intro: Platycodon mariesii, commonly known as the Korean bellflower, is a perennial herb native to East Asia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its distinctive bell-shaped flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves and blue to purple flowers. It thrives in well-drained soil and partial shade, making it a popular choice for garden cultivation. Its ornamental value is enhanced by its long blooming period and ability to attract pollinators.
